Digital Computers in Radiation Treatment Planning
items.abstract: <jats:p>Details are given of a scheme whereby treatment planning for radiotherapy may be carried out using a digital computer. A programme has been written with great generality to enable a wide range of fixed field and rotational treatment plans to be carried out. The procedure has been designed with a view to ease of operation and to produce an output on a line-printer which is immediately interpretable without any further calculations or graph plotting. Possible developments of the scheme are discussed.</jats:p>

title: REACTIONS TO FAMILY PLANNING
Economic Planning: The French Experience and La Planification Économique en France
Patterns of Language Planning in the New States
items.abstract: <jats:p>The proliferation of new sovereign states, well over sixty since World War II, has created language problems on a scale unknown in the past. In many of the emergent lands there is a great diversity of tongues, with none of them predominant. Ethnic and tribal rivalries quite often are so acute that the choice of any one language over the others would evoke stubborn opposition and fan already existing resentments. For example, Nigeria with some two hundred distinct languages simply saw fit to adopt English as the over-all official medium, although several important vernaculars are employed for primary education and local administration.</jats:p>

title: The Economics of Educational Planning : Sense and Nonsense
Coventry England, 15–18 June 1964 planning and design for protection from noise
Improve the Balance Method of Labor Planning
Critical Path Analysis for New Product Planning
items.abstract: <jats:p> Since its inception in 1957, Critical Path Analysis (CPA), which includes the CRITICAL PATH METHOD (CPM), and PROGRAM EVALUATION AND REVIEW TECHNIQUE (PERT) has received widespread acclaim as a planning, scheduling, and control tool. Its applications had been initially restricted to construction and engineering. Growing sophistication in the use of the tool has extended its applicability to the area of new product planning. </jats:p><jats:p> The purpose of this article is to introduce to marketing managers and analysts the group of techniques called CPA and its application to new product planning. The process of new product planning as a function of marketing management is first described. The concept and the underlying logic of CPA and a hypothetical new product venture are presented to show the technique's rationale and capability. Extensions of CPA and its value in a new product venture conclude the discussion. </jats:p>

Planning by Resource Allocation Methods—Illustrated by Military Applications
items.abstract: <jats:p> This paper is concerned with resource allocation problems of a somewhat general nature. For presentation convenience, the material is stated in terms of military planning, where this planning refers to the production and use of types of weapons that have already been developed. The situation can be conveniently phrased in terms of resource allocation with respect to some specified types of weapons that are to be used to attack some given targets. Consider all combinations of target and type of weapon. The problem is to distribute the total available resources (for production and use of weapons) among these combinations in such a manner that the value of the targets surviving the attack is minimized. A deterministic model of an exceedingly flexible nature is developed for representing situations of this nature. Despite the generality allowed, an elementary iterative method is obtained for solving the allocation of resources problem. These results are computer oriented and should be feasible for application even when the model is of an exceedingly complicated nature. </jats:p>

title: Social Progress Through Social Planning — the Role of Social Work
items.abstract: <jats:p> Editorial Note: The Working Party met in Chalkis, Greece from August 30 to September 6, just prior to the Twelfth International Conference of Social Work. Its report, which was designed to clarify the ideas on which the Conference programme was based and thus to serve as a guide to the Conference discussions, is printed here in full. The report was issued in English and French and was distributed to all Conference delegates when they registered. </jats:p>
